title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the dominant groundcover in the plot where a fire occurred 32 years before the data were collected as shrubs.
The response identifies the dominant groundcover in the plot where a fire occurred 32 years before the data were collected as shrubs.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the percent coverage of sedges and grasses in the unburned plot compared to that in the plot burned most recently, such as any of the following:

· There is a slightly higher percentage of sedge and grasses in the unburned plot than in the most recently burned plot.

· There is a slightly lower percentage of sedge and grasses in the plot burned two years before the data were collected than the unburned plot.

· The percentage of sedges and grasses are about the same in both plots.

· The percent cover of sedges and grasses in the unburned plot is 15%–18% compared to the most recently burned plot at 10%–12%.

The response describes the percent coverage of sedges and grasses in the unburned plot compared to that in the plot burned most recently, such as one of the following:

· There is a slightly higher percentage of sedge and grasses in the unburned plot than in the most recently burned plot.

· There is a slightly lower percentage of sedge and grasses in the plot burned two years before the data were collected than the unburned plot.

· The percentage of sedges and grasses are about the same in both plots.

· The percent cover of sedges and grasses in the unburned plot is 15%–18% compared to the most recently burned plot at 10%–12%.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim based on evidence in the graph to support or refute the hypothesis that in the Alaskan tundra area in the study, shrubs will dominate the landscape in later succession stages such as the following:

· The hypothesis is refuted because lichens (50% ground cover) dominate the unburned plot, not shrubs (28% ground cover).

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how lichen could be used as an environmental indicator species to determine if an area has high levels of acid precipitation, such as any of the following:

· Acid precipitation is a secondary pollutant formed from sulfur dioxide emissions (or from SO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabofacaqGpbWaaSbaaSqaaiaabkdaaeqaaaaa@3A82@ reacting with water and oxygen). If lichen populations decline in an area, it could indicate high levels of acid precipitation in the area.

· Acid precipitation can result from sulfur dioxide being emitted into the air from coal-burning power plants. If lichen populations decline in an area, it could indicate high levels of acid precipitation in the area.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the relationship between the average thaw depth and time since the last fire, such as any of the following:

· The average thaw depth decreased overall as the number of years since the last fire increased.

· The average thaw depth increased overall as the number of years since the last fire decreased.

· The average thaw depth and the time and the number of years since the last fire are inversely proportional.

The response describes the relationship between the average thaw depth and time since the last fire, such as one of the following:

· The average thaw depth decreased overall as the number of years since the last fire increased.

· The average thaw depth increased overall as the number of years since the last fire decreased.

· The average thaw depth and the time and the number of years since the last fire are inversely proportional.

title: Part I
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the scientist would test for nitrate levels in the soil in the study plots, such as any of the following:

· Nitrate is a limiting resource for plant growth. Therefore, measuring nitrate levels would indicate if nitrate levels are sufficient for robust plant growth or if nitrate would need to be added by organic or inorganic fertilizer.

· Wildfires alter soil nitrate levels and cause shifts in producer community composition.

· Nitrate levels increase after wildfires. Increased nitrate levels indicate a recent fire/early stage of succession.

The response explains why the scientist would test for nitrate levels in the soil in the study plots, such as one of the following:

· Nitrate is a limiting resource for plant growth. Therefore, measuring nitrate levels would indicate if nitrate levels are sufficient for robust plant growth or if nitrate would need to be added by organic or inorganic fertilizer.

· Wildfires alter soil nitrate levels and cause shifts in producer community composition.

· Nitrate levels increase after wildfires. Increased nitrate levels indicate a recent fire/early stage of succession.

title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim about the relative soil nutrient levels in silty loam soil compared to sandy loam soils such as the following:

· Silty loam soils contain less sand than sandy loam soils. As a result, silty loam soils have more ability to hold water, so nutrients are leached less, leading to higher nutrient levels than in sandy loam soils.

The response makes a claim about the relative soil nutrient levels in silty loam soil compared to sandy loam soils such as the following:
